attributes.action: End the ban on fracking
attributes.background: We want the Government to allow fracking to proceed in England, and implement planning reforms to enable shale gas developments.
attributes.additional_details:
Fracking could increase availability of cheap local energy at a time of record prices squeezing living standards and leading to inflation and higher interest rates.
 
Government policy currently forbids access to these resources. This policy should be reversed.

government_response.summary: The Government does not agree we should lift the pause on hydraulic fracturing at this time given the lack of new, compelling evidence that shale gas extraction can be done safely.
government_response.details:
In response to Putin’s barbaric acts in Ukraine and against the Ukrainian people, it is important that we keep all energy options open. While shale gas could play a part in the UK’s future energy mix, the government has always been clear that its development must be safe.

The current pause on hydraulic fracturing for shale gas was implemented in November 2019 on the basis of the difficulty in predicting and managing seismic activity caused by the process.
 
This followed hydraulic fracturing activities conducted in Lancashire that caused tremors that were widely felt by residents in surrounding areas, in some cases causing minor property damage.

Following this event, analysis conducted by the expert regulator, the North Sea Transition Authority (formerly called the Oil and Gas Authority), concluded that further analysis would be needed to confirm whether hydraulic fracturing could be done safely.

Specifically, the NSTA would need to see improvements in:

 - the prediction of whether a site will be seismogenic;

 - the prediction of the likelihood, magnitude, sequencing and timing of seismic events that could be triggered by hydraulic fracturing operations at a site; and

 - the ability to predict faults and their seismogenic susceptibility from, for example, seismic surveys.

This is needed so that more effective precautionary and mitigation measures can be considered in future hydraulic fracturing plans.

For shale gas to become a significant contributor to the UK's energy supply, a significant number of wells would need to be drilled. This is because shale gas is very different to the UK’s typical offshore gas production, where a small number of wells can be sufficient to drain the gas from an entire field. Shale gas extraction instead relies on a continued series of new wells, each of which produces gas for a relatively short time.
 
It remains government policy to minimise disruption and damage to those living and working nearby to shale gas exploration sites. Given the lack of new, compelling evidence confirming that hydraulic fracturing can be done safely, the Government does not feel it is appropriate to lift the pause on hydraulic fracturing at this time.

Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

This is a revised response. The Petitions Committee requested a response which more directly addressed the request of the petition. You can find the original response towards the bottom of the petition page (https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/608745)

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Keep The Fracking Ban
attributes.background: We would like the government to maintain the ban on fracking. We believe fracking is unsafe for the local communities that live near fracking wells, it will be bad for the environment, it’s not a short-term solution to the energy crisis, and it is opposed by much of rural England.
attributes.additional_details: The government admit that it would take years for shale gas to become an important enough part of our energy mix so fracking won't solve the current energy crisis. Also, we believe extracting shale gas would be a retrograde step when we need to move away from fossil fuels and towards renewable energy. The government should never impose fracking on communities against their will.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Reverse implementation of Freeports unless approved by a public vote
attributes.background: Stop developing areas of the country into Freeports, and reverse implementation of existing freeports, until the public is given a democratic opportunity to approve or reject them, having been fully informed about how they will impact the nation.
attributes.additional_details: There are many areas of concern: workers' rights therein, NI provision, the possibility of fracking in National Park areas, the running of them by private entities, involvement of local populations in decision-making. The public should be given the opportunity to decide if they want this policy to go ahead, following wider public debate on this policy.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Protect the Environment – support carbon neutral energy alternatives
attributes.background:
In November 2019, Members of the UK Youth Parliament, sitting in the House of Commons voted “Protect the Environment” as its campaigning priority for this year.

We are calling for the Government to ban fracking, end the mining of fossil fuels and instead support carbon neutral energy alternatives.
attributes.additional_details:
To preserve this world for the next generation, we have a moral responsibility to protect it from the effects of Climate Change. Climate change is a problem than will affect young people more than any other generation.

Right now, the Government are not protecting the environment in the way that is necessary for young people and the next generation.

http://www.ukyouthparliament.org.uk/2019/news/climate-emergency-declared-biggest-issue-facing-young-people/

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Seek to secure international ban on fracking at COP26
attributes.background: UK government announced a moratorium on fracking at start of the 2019 election campaign but left the door open to new applications to frack (unconventionally drill) in the future. We're calling on the Government to seek to agree an international, legally enforceable BAN on fracking as part of COP26.
attributes.additional_details: Residents who have campaigned to have fracking prevented in their communities, have no sense of safety and security whilst fracking is under a moratorium; we call for a legal ban on unconventional energy extraction that can put lives, health, the environment and climate at risk.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Create new publicly owned solar energy company to address fuel & climate crisis
attributes.background: Energy prices are rising to unmanageable levels & fossil fuels add to climate change. Create new publicly owned 100% solar energy company. Solar is the cheapest way to produce energy, with potentially floating solar panels on every reservoir in the country, to locally produce clean reliable energy.
attributes.additional_details: Solar tech has improved dramatically recently:  Solar power is now the cheapest way to generate electricity, cheaper than coal, oil, gas inc fracking, wind, hydro, nuclear, etc. Solar panels are now far cheaper & require less area to produce more energy than they used to, working well even on cloudy or rainy days. Solar panels can be floated on water or be placed on building roofs so don't take up any additional land, producing energy locally, with battery banks ensuring electricity is reliable & available 24/7.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Commit to UK natural gas and increase investment
attributes.background: The Government should commit to developing natural gas from UK sources as a central part of its energy policy, including north sea production and fracking. As part of the transition to non-fossil fuels, Natural Gas will surely be required for decades before 2050.
attributes.additional_details:
It is not ‘green’ to bring it in by tanker from the USA. It is political madness to expose ourselves to supplies from overseas. 

The rising cost of natural gas need not be a global problem for the UK. We surely have enough to be self-sufficient. The transition to 2050 is a marathon, not a sprint. Common sense needs to be applied to managing the transition. The solution to the fuel crisis is supply, not convoluted subsidies. It is time Government adopted the old business maxim - Keep It Simple Stupid! (KISS).

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Fund grants for installation of solar panels and battery storage for households
attributes.background: We ask the government to provide grants to all households that wish to install solar panels and battery storage. For those on the lowest incomes we ask that the grant cover the full costs of installation so the household does not carry any financial burden.
attributes.additional_details: Total UK domestic electricity consumption = 103.8 TWh. Installing solar panels on every house in the UK would provide 60.52% of our total domestic electricity consumption. Between April and September, solar generation would exceed all domestic electricity consumption. Dangers regarding nuclear power plants are well documented, as well as upfront cost & security risks. Fracking causes air water & sound pollution, for these reasons we believe solar power to be better and worth the extra funding.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Reverse fracking moratorium and provide support for natural gas extraction
attributes.background:
We the undersigned petition the UK Government to:
 
- Remove the 2019 moratorium on fracking
- Identify suitable sites for fracking
- Provide support for natural gas extraction, for supply to the UK market
attributes.additional_details:
Natural Gas prices fluctuate around the world based on supply and demand. Gas costs could be significantly cheaper in the UK if it was produced in greater volume here (as in the USA).
 
We now need to seize the benefits of home grown gas to reduce the financial burden on our citizens.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Hold a vote on re-instating the fracking ban without whips involved
attributes.background: Fracking was deemed as dangerous and a risk to  the country. Truss held a vote (19/10/22), where MPs were told regardless of their actual views, they had to agree to approve fracking or they would lose the whip ie. be thrown out of the Conservative party.  Truss is gone. Let's hold an honest vote.
attributes.additional_details:
The vote was unfair and there are allegations of bullying, manhandling amongst the fact it was said, agree with fracking or lose your membership, 'it is a vote of confidence' in the Conservative party. This was not true and that message was withdrawn AFTER the vote. It is too important an issue to be tied to a whip. MPs said that they voted against their own judgement for the sake of the whip. Liz resigned the next day and we are left with this poor result. Many of her policies have been reversed. 

Please hold an honest vote and we can abide by the honest result.

rejection.details: We can't accept your petition because the UK Government and Parliament aren't responsible for the issue you raise. Decisions on whipping are a matter for individual parties and not for the UK Government or Parliament to decide.

This dependence undermines the country’s lee room to act against gas exporters such as Russia.
Concreting over the wells is not supported by reliable science and the impact of continuing this policy is to substantially increase the cost of living.

attributes.action: Resolve the energy crisis through Green energy not by fracking or oil and gas
attributes.background: Resolve the energy crisis by investing in green energy; green energy comes on stream about as quickly as new oil and gas or fracking but doesn't harm the environment. It is also sustainable and lower cost. End the exploration of new oil and gas fields and fracking and back green energy instead.
attributes.additional_details:
Resolving our energy crisis by extracting every last drop of oil, every last whiff of gas, and by fracking will contribute to global warming. Global warming is already causing widespread problems, it would be selfish to contribute further to those.
There is no advantage to turning to oil and gas, for instance offshore wind farms can be built in about the same timescale (and in some cases faster) than new oil and gas. Green energy (on or offshore) will reduce energy prices and help the climate.

attributes.action: Ban Fracking in Lancashire (and Nationwide)
attributes.background: To vote against fracking in the UK to uphold our country's commitment to the global fight against climate change and prevent the environmental disasters caused by fracking in other countries from occurring in our country; preserving our beautiful rural areas, its wilderness and biodiversity.
attributes.additional_details: Earlier in Liz Truss's premiership she stated that fracking would go ahead in areas as long as there is local support; as a constituent of Blackpool I can categorically state that there has already been passionate resistance to previous attempts to frack in the area. Fracking cause tremors which are a threat to peoples houses and livelihoods as seen elsewhere in the world, furthermore, fracking also disrupts and displaces wildlife due to noise pollution and the destruction of natural habitats.

attributes.action: Restore the Fracking Ban
attributes.background:
The fracking ban was lifted on 22nd September against the wishes of many communities and without addressing the concerns about earth tremors and other issues.
There's no democratic mandate for lifting the ban wasn't in the last Conservative manifesto and it hasn't been approved by Parliament.
attributes.additional_details:
It'll take years for the fracking industry to develop and become economically viable if ever so it won't address the current cost of living crisis.
A large scale fracking industry will destroy swathes of our countryside that we need for growing food, for wildlife and our own wellbeing. 
Instead, we need to focus on developing renewable energy rather than fossil fuels that will pollute the planet and eventually run out.

rejection.details:
We understand you want fracking licenses to be issued, however it's not clear which projects you want such licenses to be granted to. In any case, we can't accept petitions which call for action in respect of individual businesses, including petitions calling for specified operators of energy generating facilities be granted a fracking license.

You might like to sign these petitions which call for related actions:

'End the ban on fracking': https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/608745

'Commit to UK natural gas and increase investment': https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/608274

attributes.action: Reinstate the fracking ban and up support for renewables
attributes.background: We ask that the government reinstate the ban on fracking so our country can deliver on much needed climate commitments to rapidly cut emissions, and to ensure investment in safe, resilient and zero carbon alternatives.
attributes.additional_details:
At a time when the country needs a solution to both the cost of living and climate crises, fracking will only set us back.  It will halt progress towards tackling the former, and at best providing temporary respite from the latter but with the real risk of extra investment needed to mitigate various risks associated with this water intensive, polluting and poorly regulated technology.

We call for the ban to be reinstated and for greater investment in renewable energy.

attributes.action: Amend policy to use UK fuels, including fracking, until alternatives are found.
attributes.background:
Use our own supplies of gas, coal and oil until suitable, efficient alternatives are found. 
Alternatives to be researched for supplying new builds. 
Heat pump installations used only when suitable, not if impractical and costly.
Fracking rules revised to allow extraction of shale gas, as in USA.
attributes.additional_details:
Whilst we need to reduce our emissions, we are taking a hypocritical route by using fossil fuels that are not our own. We are increasing the cost and increasing the emissions by using sea and road transport to move the fuels, especially coal. 
Replacing central heating systems and building wind farms might help towards reducing our emissions, but production of these items causes more emissions than we are saving. We should take into account that many of the redundant items cannot be recycled.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you want to see changes to energy policy, but we're not sure exactly what you'd like the Government or Parliament to do. For example, it's not clear if you want the Government to ban all imports of fossil fuels, or what if any changes you want to be made to grants for heat pumps.

We have published the following petitions, which you might like to sign:

Commit to UK natural gas and increase investment: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/608274

End the ban on fracking: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/608745

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.
